title: Brian Darling
text:
Brian Darling (born 1965) is the president and founder of the firm Liberty Government Affairs. He was Senior Communications Director and Counsel for Senator <a href="Rand%20Paul">Rand Paul</a> (R-KY) and a former senior fellow in government studies at <a href="The%20Heritage%20Foundation">The Heritage Foundation</a>, a <a href="conservativism">conservative</a> <a href="think-tank">think-tank</a> based in <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> Darling has been involved in U.S. politics since the early 1990s, in roles as a congressional aide, lobbyist and legal counsel. Darling came to national media attention when he resigned as legal counsel to <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a> Senator <a href="Mel%20Martinez">Mel Martinez</a> of <a href="Florida">Florida</a> after admitting he was the author of the "<a href="Schiavo%20memo">Schiavo memo</a>."
Early life and education.
Darling was born and grew up in <a href="Andover%2C%20Massachusetts">Andover, Massachusetts</a>. He attended the <a href="University%20of%20Massachusetts%20Amherst">University of Massachusetts Amherst</a>, where he launched a conservative student publication, "The Minuteman", with fellow student <a href="Tony%20Rudy">Tony Rudy</a>. Darling received his <a href="Juris%20Doctor">Juris Doctor</a> degree from the <a href="New%20England%20School%20of%20Law">New England School of Law</a>.
Career.
Darling joined the U.S. Congress as an aide to <a href="Idaho">Idaho</a> Senator <a href="Steve%20Symms">Steve Symms</a> in 1992. The following year, Darling worked for <a href="Georgia%20%28U.S.%20state%29">Georgia</a> Senator <a href="Paul%20Coverdell">Paul Coverdell</a>.
Darling became General Counsel to <a href="New%20Hampshire">New Hampshire</a> Senator <a href="Robert%20C.%20Smith">Bob Smith</a> in 1999. In January 2000, he and Senator Smith visited <a href="Cubans">Cuban</a> refugee <a href="Eli%C3%A1n%20Gonz%C3%A1lez">Elián González</a> before proposing legislation to grant González permanent residency. He was also a member of the <a href="George%20W.%20Bush">Bush</a>-<a href="Dick%20Cheney">Cheney</a> recount team in Florida during the <a href="U.S.%20presidential%20election%2C%202000">2000 presidential election controversy</a> and co-chairman of the Conservative Working Group, a weekly legislative strategy meeting of staffers from House and Senate offices.
In 2003, Darling became a partner in the <a href="Alexander%20Strategy%20Group">Alexander Strategy Group</a> lobbying firm, where he advocated for <a href="Gun%20politics%20in%20the%20United%20States">gun rights</a> and other issues. He was a chief strategist for Senate legislation permitting <a href="aviator">airline pilots</a> to carry handguns on the job.
In 2005, Darling became a legal counsel to <a href="Florida">Florida</a> Senator <a href="Mel%20Martinez">Mel Martinez</a>. He resigned from the position in May of that year following a controversy involving a strategy memo he had written based on the <a href="Terri%20Schiavo%20case">Terri Schiavo case</a>. Later that year, Darling became director of United States Senate relations for <a href="The%20Heritage%20Foundation">The Heritage Foundation</a>, where he was responsible for educating Senators and their staff about Heritage's latest research and policy recommendations.
During his time with Heritage, Darling wrote a research paper on the filibuster titled “The Filibuster Protects the Rights of All Senators and the American People,” and one on the Balanced Budget Amendment to the Constitution.
Darling was also a frequent spokesman for Heritage on Fox, Fox Business, MSNBC, and CNN. While at the Heritage Foundation, Darling had a regular column at Human Events and was a contributor to the websites RedState.com, Townhall.com, and BigGovernment.com. 
After his time at Heritage, he wrote for "<a href="The%20Observer%20%28Kearny%2C%20New%20Jersey%29">The Observer</a>". From 2012 to 2015, Darling served as both Counsel and Sr. Communications Director for Sen. <a href="Rand%20Paul">Rand Paul</a> (R-KY). In 2017, Darling founded the government relations firm Liberty Government Affairs to conduct public relations, <a href="lobbying">lobbying</a>, and outreach to the liberty movement.
Schiavo memo.
The <a href="Schiavo%20memo">Schiavo memo</a> was a <a href="talking%20point">talking point</a>s memorandum on behalf of the Republican party, which described the ongoing Terri Schiavo case as "a great political issue" that could appeal to the party's <a href="Base%20%28politics%29">base</a>.
Senator Martinez, who claimed not to have read the memo, had inadvertently passed it to <a href="Iowa">Iowa</a> Senator <a href="Tom%20Harkin">Tom Harkin</a>, a <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democratic</a> supporter of the legislation to keep Schiavo alive. National media outlets began reporting the existence of the memo shortly thereafter on March 18, 2005. On April 6, 2005, Darling admitted to writing the memo and resigned his position as legal counsel to Martinez.
